text: - My name is Noam Shaish.
I'm a Chief Engineer in BMW.
So we came from a on-prem cluster.
Like any on-prem cluster,
you could physically extend it.
But forecasting the physical needs

like the hardware needs for
this cluster is pretty hard.

As new technologies comes
in to solve the challenges
of the AWS development,
there's also an increasing need for data.

So more data, vast variety
of data that is required.
And that's a challenge.
AWS brings in their own expertise

of clouds and we bring the
domain knowledge in it.
AWS also brought in the cooperation
their autonomous experts,
and it's kind of helped us
to really quickly bring up a product

and a platform for the
autonomous driving development.
We use technologies like EC2
and EKS in order to enable
the high amount of reprocessing

and different simulation
scenarios that we have.
And we use serverless technologies
like Lambda functions and DynamoDB
in order to label the scenarios.
And we also use machine learning

and AI mainly, I mean,
on the cluster itself,

to do different labeling of
the interesting scenarios.
This is exciting for us

because we could really bring
up functionality much faster
and in newer technologies and bring in
and try out new approaches
alongside with the classical approaches,
which was very hard without AWS.

So in the end of the day, our
customer's getting a product

that was validated both for all
the regulatory requirements,
but more than that, for BMW standards.

And that's only possible when
you have vast amount of data
and vast amount of computation going on
and continuously checking
and validating the software that we have.
(upbeat music)
